item.title: Serbia, Kosovo Agree to Normalize Economic Relations
item.description: The two Balkan nations are working to resolve a decadeslong dispute that once prompted a U.S. military intervention in the region.

item.title: Oil Industry Is Fading Away in Land of the World's Richest Reserves
item.description: Venezuela sees its production dwindle after decades of graft and mismanagement under Chávez and Maduro regimes, and now the burden of U.S. sanctions. The last drilling rig in the country has shut down.

item.title: In Belarus, Torture Allegations Dog Lukashenko as He Tries to Keep Power
item.description: For more than two decades, President Alexander Lukashenko has used torture to cement his grip on power in Belarus, activists and opponents say. The U.S. and Europe have condemned a violent crackdown on protesters since he claimed victory in August’s election.

item.title: Coronavirus Cases Surge in France as People Return to Schools, Offices
item.description: France’s virus infections are surging as the public returns to offices and schools after the summer vacation, putting authorities on high alert about gathering places that could accelerate the spread.

item.title: Beirut Rescuers Search for Possible Survivor One Month After Explosion
item.description: A rescue team stepped up a search for a survivor of the Beirut port explosion, after detecting a possible pulse amid the rubble caused by the massive blast one month ago.

item.title: Brazil's Vice President Admits Mistakes in Fighting Amazon Deforestation
item.description: Hamilton Mourão, leader of Brazil’s Amazon-protection task force, says the government hasn’t directed enough resources toward reducing deforestation, which has skyrocketed in the past two years as land grabbers and wildcat ranchers have moved deeper into the world’s largest rainforest.
